groupHeaders: 1. Get into and out of the tub or shower
2. Dress your lower body
3. Get on and off the toilet
4. Get up from the floor
5. Balance while standing
6. Stand for one-half hour
7. Pick up an object from floor while standing
8. Get up from a chair
9. Get into and out of a car
10. Walk around indoors
11. Walk outside on uneven ground
12. Walk in bad weather (e.g., rain, snow, wind)
13. Walk up to two hours
14. Walk up a steep ramp
15. Get on and off an escalator
16. Climb one flight of stairs with a rail
17. Climb one flight of stairs without a rail
18. Run one block
19. Carry a plate of food while walking
20. Put on and take off orthosis or prosthesis
instructions: Instruct your patient to respond to all of the questions with the response that most closely reflects their opinion.
mcid_mdc:
MDC = Minimal Detectable Change

Upper and Lower Extremity Prosthesis, Lower Extremity Orthosis, Orthopedic Shoes: MDC = 12.1.
Unilateral Lower Limb Amputation: MDC = 10.3.

These are published values for specific populations and provide guidance if the patient does not have the listed condition.
overview: The Orthotics and Prosthetics User’s Survey (OPUS) is a subjective patient questionnaire that consists of five sections and is used to assess multiple facets of life for prosthesis and/or orthosis users. The Lower Extremity Functional Status portion is used to assess a prosthesis and/or orthosis user’s lower extremity functional capacity in activities of daily living.
population: The intended population includes the following conditions: Limb Loss and Amputation, Orthopedic Surgery, and Mixed Population of Orthosis and Prosthesis Users.

1. Bettoni E, Ferriero G, Bakhsh H, et al. A systematic review of questionnaires to assess patient satisfaction with limb orthoses. Prosthet Orthot Int. 2016;40(2):158-169. doi:10.1177/0309364614556836

score_calculation: Items are based on a Likert scale (0-4) as follows: 4 = Very easy, 3 = Easy, 2 = Slightly difficult, 1 = Very difficult, 0 = Cannot do this activity. The sum of the 20 questions creates a raw score of 0-80. These raw scores are then converted into the Rasch Measure which is on a scale of 0-100.
score_interpretation: The score is represented on a 0-100 scale where 100 represents the most function and 0 represents the least function.
